subject: Re: [junit] Need to test a method that returns void

messageBody:
About putting each try/catch in its own test method, I agree ;-)
About the requirements, that was just an example.

Tiago

On 4/20/06, jason r tibbetts <tibbettj@...> wrote:
>
> Tiago Fernandez wrote:
> > Ok, I'm still moving to JUnit4, so I'll show you an example I have with
> > JUnit3:
> >
> > /**
> > * Trying to login with username and password
> > */
> > public void testLoginValidation() throws Exception {
> > try {
> > securityHandler.login("pt", "portugiesisch");
> > fail("Username with 2 characters must not be allowed.");
> > }
> > catch (Exception ex) {
> > // passed :-)
> > }
> > try {
> > securityHandler.login("deutsch", "de");
> > fail("Password with 2 characters must not be allowed.");
> > }
> > catch (Exception ex) {
> > // passed :-)
> > }
> > try {
> > securityHandler.login("", "");
> > fail("Blank username and password must not be allowed.");
> > }
> > catch (Exception ex) {
> > // passed :-)
> > }
> > }
> >
> > Please let me know if it's enough.
>
> Look at your application's requirements to determine whether it's
> enough. I can think of many, many more tests that you may want to do:
>
> * username or password with 1 character
> * separate tests for blank password and blank username (otherwise, how
> do you know which one triggered the exception?)
> * more specific exception handling
> * null arguments
> * validating that a successful login actually /does/ something (i.e. try
> accessing a resources that required being logged in)
> * etc.
>
> I also recommend putting each one of these try/catch blocks in its own
> test method. This will make it much easier to debug failed tests and to
> understand what's being tested.
>
